title: Friday, 21st July, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:01 am
PM11:01am

Hi there

PM11:02am

Wanna know what a pile of stolen crypto looks like?

PM11:02am

Here

11:02 am
PM11:02am

PM11:02am

That's where $30m worth of ether went this week.

PM11:02am

There's $20m left -- according to that

11:02 am
PM11:03am

I'm not sure whether the missing $10m is cos of a collapse in the price of ether

PM11:03am

Or whether a load has been transferred out somewhere else

PM11:03am

These heists are happening on a very regular basis

11:03 am
PM11:03am

But then it's just clown money, right? So it doesn't matter

PM11:04am

Here's the detail on that https://www.bleepi...worth-of-ethereum/

PM11:04am

And the actual dodgy wallet address

11:04 am
PM11:04am

https://etherscan....32a65829cd1ddb4d32

PM11:04am

Since we started the ICOmedy series, naturally being inundated by stuff

PM11:05am

And, occasionally, getting interesting comments

11:05 am
PM11:05am

Note sure whether this link works -- direct to said comment

PM11:05am

https://ftalphavil...ubRefSrc=permalink

PM11:05am

An extract...

11:05 am
PM11:06am

FT et al monotonously use current failures as evidence, and imply that the (admittedly) impending crash is vindication …but all this fuss over (ICO/crypto) failure overlooks the simple reality that some success exists in amongst this failure. It's a bit sad that these forums will likely overlook 'the next amzn'. Some crypto communities generally appreciate the intelligent doubts of mainstream media - you may be surprised to know how hotly debated your concerns are ..and the subsequent evolution/development that follows into the crypto industry. But that is exactly the point: find another global system evolving as quickly as public blockchains. Difficult for fiat maximalists. I don't mean to be disrespectful but thank goodness for the crazy pioneers, aka people with purpose beyond the security of their paycheck/investment. P.s. fiat & global banking have some problems of their own. Plus most of us youngsters feel justified trying to create a better system (than the one that involves us paying back your debt & covering the future healthcare bill with our taxes ..debate for another day though) - maybe we won't be successful, but the motivation is in no short supply & I personally know more htan 11 ICO's who have the resources to last a crash&decade (the "Amazon contingency plan") and have every intention of accruing value to their tokenholders (because their primary wealth is tied up in their own tokens: **d forbid even one of them succeeds & a public chain can scale - disruption does actually happen sometimes.

PM11:06am

Ive belatedly realised that as much as this clown money coming from a wingnut philosophy...

PM11:06am

It's also about people just reacting against the establishment

11:06 am
PM11:07am

Which we've seen and are seeing everywhere

PM11:07am

Biggest example of which is

PM11:07am

https://twitter.com/realDonaldTrump/status/888128621784838144

11:07 am
undefined
PM11:07am

But let's do real life stocks

PM11:07am

And hopefully keep ourselves sane

11:07 am
PM11:07am

ish

PM11:07am

What do you reckon Bryce?

BE11:08am

Well, okay. There are a few things happening, in spite of it being school breakup day before the holidays.

11:08 am
PM11:08am

(PeterC -- i will look into that)

BE11:09am

There's even a bid!

Paysafe Group PLC (PAYS:LSE): Last: 582.50, up 40.5 (+7.47%), High: 591.50, Low: 580.00, Volume: 5.58m
11:09 am
BE11:09am

........ sort of.

PM11:09am

Why only sort of?

BE11:09am

Well, it's complicated.

11:09 am
PM11:10am

Looks like a bid to me

BE11:10am

Blackstone and CVC to acquire Paysafe Group Plc at 590p per share, which to state the obvious is not really much of a premium.

PM11:10am

https://www.invest...1707210701017233L/

11:10 am
PM11:10am

Ah, but they are citing the "pre-consolidation frenzy" in the sector

PM11:11am

To get to the required 30%

PM11:11am

Premium wise

11:10 am
BE11:11am

Sure, sure. But more importantly, it's contingent on the disposal of Asian Gateway.

PM11:11am

Ah

BE11:11am

This is the problem bit of Paysafe, the Chinese facing bit.

11:11 am
PM11:11am

Doesnt surprise me

BE11:11am

(The most problematic bit, I should probably say.)

BE11:12am

Which was central to the short seller attack earlier in the year, and has long been in the models at nearly zero.

11:12 am
BE11:12am

Even though it's 13% of Paysafe sales and c.15% of EBITDA.

BE11:13am

It's been a line of speculation for a while that Paysafe would exit Asian Gateway somehow, possibly by disposal.

BE11:13am

Maybe those talks are further on than previously indicated? Perhaps this is all choreographed? Dunno.

11:13 am
PM11:14am

They've also got a bit bolt on today. Must be busy round there

PM11:14am

https://www.invest...1707210701017232L/

BE11:14am

That's the second oddity, yes.

11:14 am
BE11:14am

Buying Merchant’s Choice Payment Solutions for $470m in cash.

BE11:14am

Does 60,000 merchants in 50 US states.

BE11:15am

Handling $14bn of payments.

11:15 am
BE11:15am

Though there's existing overlap via Paysafe's Meritus subsidiary, which complicates things.

BE11:15am

Splitting that out, you're looking at 2016 1.4x EV/Sales and 9.6x
EV/EBITDA.

BE11:16am

Which is rather more generous than the offer for Paysafe itself.

11:15 am
PM11:16am

hmm

BE11:16am

In spite of that, Old Mut's accepted.

BE11:16am

10% shareholder.

11:16 am
BE11:16am

Though, in a non-binding way.

PM11:16am

non--binding letter of support

BE11:16am

Sellside generally saying "this looks too cheap".

11:16 am
BE11:17am

Canaccord.

BE11:17am

We have argued in previous research that Paysafe should dispose of the Asia Gateway business and this would lead to the company being a more attractive target for consolidation. With this morning's approach it appears that whatever the outcome it is likely the Asia Gateway business will be sold. We believe that as a standalone entity this should provide a re-rating. If we assume that Asia Gateway represents 20% of earnings and the business rerates from 15x earnings to 20x earnings, this provides c. 7% potential upside to the stock from yesterday's close of 542p i.e. c580p excluding the proceeds from Asia Gateway which, based on 8x earnings, could be worth 55p per share.

BE11:18am

And Macquarie.

11:18 am
BE11:18am

 We estimate Blackstone and CVC are paying 11.5x–12.7x 2018E EBITDA for Paysafe after the sale of the Asian Gateway and including the acquisition MCPS.
 We believe this is a fair value compared other payment companies currently in bid discussions: 14.8x for Worldpay and 11.6x for Nets. Both are lower-risk businesses. Note also that MCPS is a lower-growth, lower-margin business that should lower growth prospects and valuation for Paysafe.

BE11:18am

And Barclays.

BE11:18am

In the last weeks we have experienced rapid consolidation of digital payment assets. Paysafe has always been an undervalued asset, partly as the Asian gateway acted as a poison pill. If this business would be sold we would expect its valuation would anyway normalise, which is not reflected in the PE bid. Wirecard is currently trading at 13x FY19 EBITDA and Bambora was acquired yesterday at 15x FY19 EBITDA including €30m synergies and 21x if excluded. We therefore see the current bid as opportunistic and advise investors to adjust the price for Paysafe for the accretion of the deal (we calculate 12-18%) and valuation paid for other digital assets.

The company is currently trading at 9.2x EV/EBITDA and 13x PE and we reiterate our Overweight and 610p target which doesn’t include the 12-18% accretion for the proposed M&A.

11:19 am
BE11:19am

And UBS.

BE11:20am

[W]e would initially highlight that on first impressions
the acquisition appears to make sense, is not a particularly high multiple in the context of payments and we would estimate potential EPS accretion of c10%. Regarding the offer we believe further information would be necessary before being able to comment - particularly around the value generated in the Asia Gateway business which has been a drag on Paysafe's multiple

BE11:20am

They'd been on a 575p target.

11:20 am
PM11:20am

Can't see any mention there of Paysafe being quiet heavily reliant on online gambling.

PM11:20am

Which I think it is

BE11:21am

Yep.

11:20 am
PM11:21am

Surely merchant quality/mix is important here

PM11:21am

Certainly from a risk perspective

PM11:21am

Actually, thinking about it -- probably easier to deal with those risks under PE ownership than in front of us. Censored

11:22 am
BE11:22am

Well ............ To announce on the same day the acquisition of a rather dull looking US payments processor on the same day as the rather lowball take-private bid and the initial terms of the Asian disposal ......

BE11:23am

....... it's quite a lot to digest, and one can argue that the company Blackstone/CVC will (might) be buying isn't the same one as was owned by shareholders

BE11:23am

.... and shorted by shorters.

11:23 am
BE11:23am

In all, it's a rather confusing development in a company that's spent a long time confusing people.

PM11:23am

Indeed

undefined
11:24 am
BE11:24am

While on M&A, Credit Suisse has a big cross-sector thing out

BE11:24am

Including the long list of companies that screen as targets, which is always fun.

BE11:24am

Three part thesis:

11:24 am
BE11:24am

Sterling's crapout, of course, making everything in the UK cheaper.

BE11:25am

But also, no letup in Chinese M&A, in spite of the restrictions on capital outflows.

BE11:25am

Nearly 20% of global M&A activity has been driven by Chinese acquirers, apparently.

11:25 am
BE11:25am

And finally, activists badgering for stuff.

BE11:25am

Activists have $187bn under management in 2017, from $144bn in 2013

BE11:25am

And 111 European companies receiving activist demands in 2016, up from 80 in 2015.

11:25 am
BE11:25am

Cool tables included.

BE11:25am

BE11:25am

11:25 am
BE11:26am

But anyway, here's the target screen.

BE11:26am

BE11:26am

11:26 am

PM11:26am

If it's just on the number of campaigns, taht doesnt tell us much

PM11:27am

Just says which activists have ADHD / make a lot of noise

11:27 am
BE11:27am

Yeah, it's just a quant screen counting the number. "Influential" is perhaps the wrong heading.

PM11:27am

And Bryce -- Ocado at the top of the target list ?!?!?!

BE11:28am

Yeah, CS has a thesis that Ocado's going to be entirely robotised by 2025.

11:28 am

Yeah, we've seen the Ocado self driving go carts

BE11:29am

Those autonomous milkfloats will make it cheaper than going to Tesco and shopping for yourself, CS says.

PM11:29am

11:29 am

BE11:30am

The note was rather lacking in detail on which patents the analyst found, but I guess there must be some.

PM11:30am

(BornCynic -- I have to cover Neil Collins column for tomorrow's paper, so saving Albert for that)

11:30 am
BE11:30am

Anyway, that's that.

PM11:01am

Welcome to Markets Live

PM11:30am

We've kinda ignored Acacia Mining

11:30 am
PM11:31am

It's been in a real mess in Tanzania

PM11:31am

Tanzania making the sorts of allegations that were so extreme they were unbelievable

PM11:31am

Colossal under-reporting by Acacia, allegedly

11:31 am
PM11:31am

Anyway, the company seems to be working hard a simmering everything down locally

PM11:32am

But it's not helping the share price much

Acacia Mining PLC (ACA:LSE): Last: 259.30, down 21.5 (-7.66%), High: 269.30, Low: 248.30, Volume: 2.13m
11:32 am
BE11:32am

The Q2 results are actually surprisingly decent, given Acacia can't actually sell any gold.

PM11:32am

This was about 420p in May

BE11:32am

Has 127koz stockpiled awaiting resolution, which seems no nearer.

11:33 am
PM11:33am

Surely Tanzania wants the royalties

BE11:34am

Yes, though can Tanzania wait longer than Acacia Mining to get a deal over how much those royalties should be?

PM11:34am

Well that's a point.

11:34 am
PM11:34am

And the Tanzanians might have a view on the price going forward...

PM11:34am

Statement here btw https://www.invest...170721070000PD440/

BE11:35am

So ............ negotiations are the only thing that matter here

11:35 am
BE11:36am

Here's Barclays.

BE11:36am

Acacia reported surprisingly strong Q2-17 results under the current circumstances, driven mostly by non-cash share-based payments and a credit relating to the build-up in finished gold inventory in the P&L. Looking at the more important cash flow, Q2 FCF was c.$-70m, reflecting $53m in taxes and royalties and build-up of 127koz gold in concentrate. Net cash at the end of period was $90.7m (c.$165m end of May, $196m in March). Q2 gold production of 209koz was down 5% QoQ (-6% YoY), while AISC was down 11% QoQ (-10% YoY) to $835/oz (incl credit of $18/oz for share based payments), beating expectations. Gold sales of 128oz reflects the implementation of the concentrate export ban from 2 March. H1 AISC would have been $800/oz had sales equaled production during the period. H1 EBITDA of $166m is 3% ahead of consensus. 2017 production is now targeted at the bottom end of the 850-900koz range, while AISC cost guidance was left unchanged at $880-920/oz including new royalty and clearing fee. Capex guidance is now $180-200m vs $220m previously. As previously announced, the company has served International Arbitration notices to the government. Management notes that while a negotiated settlement with the Government is the preferred outcome, the situation at Buly is not sustainable beyond the end of the current quarter. If this asset is shut, the one-off costs would be c.$30m upfront plus the cost of unwinding accounts payable and ongoing care-and-maintenance costs of c.$2-3m.

BE11:37am

So, you have Acacia burning $10-15m per month and negotiations -- which are involving Barrick, not Acacia directly -- haven't even started yet.

11:37 am
BE11:37am

That's post the ban coming in on March 2.

PM11:38am

Yeah, that's not so hopeful

BE11:38am

I think it's best to assume they're going to mothball operations

11:38 am
BE11:38am

But even then, we're looking at a $2-3m cash burn.

BE11:38am

It's bleak stuff.

PM11:39am

(I had a lovely dinner last night with one of our regular readers. One thing he said: "You'll never leave Africa with more than the shirt on your back.")

11:39 am
BE11:39am

(Fair.)

BE11:39am

Citi incoming.

BE11:40am

Recent regulatory changes include 1) Government's right to renegotiate existing mineral development agreements at its discretion; 2) minimum and non-dilutable 16% free carried interest of govt. in all mining projects; 3) govt. can acquire up to 50% of any mining asset commensurate with tax benefits; 4) removal of input VAT refund; 5) increase in royalties to 6% from 4%; 6) local beneficiation and procurement; 7) constraints on off-shore bank accounts; 8) government lien over material extracted from mines; 9) 1% clearance fee to obtain export clearance.

11:40 am
undefined
PM11:40am

For the record -- Africa's a big place. Unfair to generalised

PM11:41am

AO World

11:41 am
PM11:41am

AGM statement earlier

PM11:41am

But not much price reaction

AO World PLC (AO.:LSE): Last: 120.00, up 1 (+0.84%), High: 122.75, Low: 119.50, Volume: 98.39k
11:41 am
PM11:41am

Almost none actually

BE11:41am

Sales growth slowing, not unexpectedly.

PM11:41am

https://www.invest...1707210700026920L/

11:41 am
PM11:42am

George Mensah at Shore really not a fan

PM11:42am

Ahead of its Annual General Meeting this morning, AO has provided a trading update for the first quarter of FY2018 (1st April 2017 to 30th June 2017). As expected, growth has slowed in its core UK market with challenging conditions cited, particularly in the major domestic appliances (MDA) market. However, positive momentum from Q4 FY2017 continued into Q1 FY2018 for the European business with sales up c58%. We have updated our forecasts for the company for FY2018, with our revenue estimate pulling back by c2% to £780.2m. In terms of EBITDA, we have reduced our estimate from £3.5m to £1.1m (which on a relative basis is a significant delta, albeit on an absolute basis represents a small profit reduction). We remain sellers of the stock as we still have concerns about a lack of differentiation against its competitive set whilst the consumer dynamic for big-ticket spending in the UK is weakening, in our view. SELL.

BE11:42am

Major domestic appliances sales correlate with house sales, of course.

11:42 am
PM11:43am

that's true

BE11:43am

Plus you have the usual problems of imported inflation and suchlike, which is why I say none of this is a surprise.

BE11:44am

Quick line from Morgan Stanley on the call.

11:44 am
BE11:44am

There is nothing about profitability in the statement, but on the call management said they expect that a majority of the price increases from suppliers had gone through in the market. This could ease some gross margin pressure; however, we note that sales are still increasing in lower margin product categories which could put further pressure on margins. The shares have been weak into results and expectations were low, so while these results are largely in line, we continue to be cautious given the slowing growth in the MDA market and AO's unproven ability to gain significant market share outside of its core MDA category.

BE11:45am

Yep. AO's reputation is good on fridges, which are a pain to get delivered. They have no particular edge selling tellies, which aren't.

undefined
11:46 am
PM11:46am

It's Friday

PM11:46am

Not that with everyone talking about passive funds, activism is suddenly back in vogue

PM11:47am

yes really

11:46 am
PM11:47am

PM11:47am

PM11:47am

PM11:47am

PM11:47am

11:47 am

BE11:48am

BE11:48am

The data look pretty noisy.

11:49 am
BE11:49am

What cause those spikes in active demand in late 2015, for instance?

BE11:49am

undefined
11:49 am
BE11:50am

Sellside wise .............

BE11:50am

There's a Carillion downgrade from Cenkos, but they seem to have forgotten to send me it. [Cough]

BE11:50am

And there's Investec on Paddy Power, which is the two step downgrade manoeuvre.

11:50 am
BE11:51am

Following lacklustre share price performance over the past six months (down 10%), recently reaching an all-time post-merger low, we take a closer look at Paddy Power Betfair. We expect the market to be surprised by what we expect will be a disappointing Q217 and H117 (we forecast Q217/H117 growth of 4%/6.5% in revenue and -9.8%/22.1% in EBITDA). We cut our target price from £100 to £69.70, on lower forecasts and a worsening regulatory outlook in the UK and Australia, and downgrade to SELL from Buy.

BE11:51am

The long and short of it: In the long run, Paddy Power Betfair is well positioned given its exposure to Online sports betting, listed market dominance in the UK and Australia, competitive advantages (Betfair’s Exchange, brand strength and scale), operational gearing and a strong balance sheet. We anticipate material consolidation post the Triennial Review outcome (expected November 2017), with the company likely playing a part. PPB should remain among the top 5 global listed online gambling stocks and so still deserves a premium rating, though below the current level (which we analyse in detail). However, shorter-term we see downside with tough comps given the Euros, consensus still absorbing punter-friendly sports results and the Draft acquisition as well as a worsening regulatory outlook.

BE11:52am

I think we've noted here several times the idea of GVC going in for William Hill post the Triennial Review.

11:52 am
GVC Holdings PLC (GVC:LSE): Last: 768.00, up 3 (+0.39%), High: 776.00, Low: 764.00, Volume: 156.73k
William Hill PLC (WMH:LSE): Last: 247.00, down 1.7 (-0.68%), High: 250.00, Low: 247.00, Volume: 734.52k
BE11:52am

Which appears to be a widespread bit of speculation.

11:52 am
BE11:53am

Operational leverage: We calculate operating leverage using LFL (CC, excl. anomalous events) 2-year LTM CAGR for revenue and EBITDA to Q417 and find that for every 1% change in revenue, EBITDA should change by 1.28%. We estimate LTM CC EBITDA growth (excluding Euros and Cheltenham) of 19.1%/14.7% for Q416/Q117.
Forecasts: We lower FY17E revenue by 3.5% and EBITDA by 1.3%, mainly due to weaker GWMs. For FY18E, we cut revenue by 4.5% and EBITDA by 5%.
Valuation: We revise our target price from £100 to £69.70 on reduced forecasts with lower assumed multiples for regulated and divisional revenue in Australia and the UK. The shares currently trade on a consensus EV/EBITDA of 11.4x (a 44% premium); we value them at an adjusted EV/EBITDA of 11.0x for FY18E

PM11:54am

11:55 am

BE11:56am

Goldman cautious on SSP? That's something.

BE11:56am

We initiate coverage of SPP with a Neutral rating. SSP is focusing on the structurally growing air segment which should underpin LFL growth while strong commercial focus and management execution should support contract wins. We also expect the company to benefit from strong operating leverage of the business model while searching for further efficiencies. However the share price is trading at 22.6x CY18E P/E which in our view largely reflects the growth outlook, hence with 4% upside to our target price pf 512p we are Neutral rated.

11:56 am
BE11:56am

It's not an interesting something, but it's something.

SSP Group PLC (SSPG:LSE): Last: 492.90, down 1.6 (-0.32%), High: 495.70, Low: 486.30, Volume: 238.18k
undefined
11:58 am
BE11:58am

...... and I think we've run out of road for the week. I can think of literally nothing else to mention.

BE11:59am

Oh! Purplebricks. That'll do.

Purplebricks Group PLC (PURP:LSE): Last: 492.98, up 18.48 (+3.89%), High: 514.00, Low: 478.00, Volume: 588.04k
11:59 am
BE11:59am

We can, somewhat arbitrarily, pin today's strength on a UBS sector note.

BE12:00pm

It is arbitrary though, because I seriously doubt the retail punters buying Purplebricks are UBS research clients.

BE12:00pm

They're more ADVFN than UBS.

12:00 pm
BE12:01pm

For them, here's the gist of it.

BE12:01pm

The latest iteration of our UBS Evidence Lab UK property listings tracker for Jul-17 points to a number of trends; (1) Subject to Contracts (STC) listings return to y-o-y growth, with a reduction in the ratio of active to STC listings indicating the market remains stable; (2) In London, STC listings have stabilised as we annualise against Mar-16 transaction spike, though the slowdown remains central London (Zones 1-2) focused, with the ratio of active to STC listings at 3.4x vs. 1.3x in the UK ex London; (3) The proportion of stock with price reductions is still rising in London, currently at 35%; and (4) Purplebricks continues to consistently gain market share, with over 4% of STC listings based on our analysis, and overtaking Countrywide for the first time.

BE12:01pm

Consistent with recent trends, the London market remains weakest, with 3.4x the number of properties listed as currently unsold vs. those subject to contracts in Zones 1-2, compared to less than 2x up until 2016. However, it is outer London zones where there has been the largest change in the proportion of homes listed at a reduced price, at 34% vs. a low of 18% in February 2016.

12:01 pm
PM12:01pm

https://uk.trustpi...w/purplebricks.com

BE12:01pm

Purplebricks continues to gain share, and shrugs off market softness
After a blip towards the end of the year, Purplebricks has continued to see strong market share growth through in the last three months. Purplebricks has nearly 3.2% market share on active listings outside of London, and on a UK-wide basis c.4% of STC listings. Whilst the company continues to lag on market share gains in London, this is in particular central London focused, with just 1.2% market share in zones 1-2 compared to 2.7% in zones 3-6.

PM12:02pm

Positive trustpilot reviews for this thing go up at the rate of one every 10 minutes, it seems

12:02 pm
BE12:02pm

Ah.

BE12:02pm

UBS likes Foxtons for the cash, and dislikes Countrywide for the trend.

BE12:03pm

The other thing on Purplebricks I was meaning to mention was Amazon

12:03 pm
BE12:03pm

Which last week put a "Hire Realtor" tab on Amazon.com

BE12:04pm

https://www.amazon...ltor/dp/B00V6D6MZ2

BE12:04pm

What does this mean? Dunno. But it gives Anthony Codling at Jefferies another chance to roll out his elegant bear case.

12:04 pm
BE12:05pm

[Amazon] would, in our view, add a significant level of risk to Purplebricks' US Expansion plan. Amazon has changed the way this analyst shops for most things and housing could be just another product purchased through a trusted brand.

BE12:05pm

History is punctuated by Davids beating Goliaths and we are not
ruling out a win here for Purplebricks, although the odds maybe uneven as Amazon became what it is today following the path of David rather than Goliath.

BE12:05pm

He also brings in the Taylor Review on Purplebricks' Uber-like solution to the inconvenience of having employees.

12:05 pm
BE12:06pm

The Taylor Review of Modern Working Practices published this week suggests that the UK creates a new category of employee, the 'Dependent Contractor' - where a contractor is dependent on one contract, the contractor should provide benefits (pensions, holidays, sick pay etc) and pay taxes (National Insurance) in a similar way to traditional employees.
The law is sometimes an Ass. Purplebricks have always told us that lawyers have agreed that LPEs are not employees, but some times the law is an Ass and sometimes the law can change. If LPEs the dependent contractor definition becomes law and LPEs are deemed to be dependent contractors, there may be significant cost implications for Purplebricks.

BE12:06pm

And then, of course ............

BE12:06pm

At current levels, PB trades on a CY2018 PER of 123.0x against the sector trading on 14.9x and an EV/EBITDA of 87.5x (sector 9.3x).

12:06 pm
BE12:07pm

.... which is a lot to pay for an unproven house seller that won't tell us how many houses it actually sells.

BE12:07pm

Good luck to the punters tho.

undefined
12:07 pm
PM12:07pm

I think we are done

PM12:07pm

Thanks for getting us through Bryce
